answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
I agree that more strategic and smarter use of technology is one of the strategies local governments need to use to reach the 20-40 age demographic. The other thing is to simply be where they are rather than always expecting them to come to you.  Have displays set up at the area grocery stores and farmer markets...use table tents at local restaurants to educate about a new comp plan...conduct polls at Little League, socceer, PeeWee football games...use the listservs of appropriate social groups/networks, i.e., bike clubs, hiking groups, etc., to solicit feedback.  If we're serious about engaging our citizens, we need to rethink how we reach them.  As Wayne Gretzky is so often quoted, "I skate to where the puck will be."

answers.text:
Barry, 
One way to increase civic participation in the 20-40 age group is to augment your conventional public meetings with online public comment forums (OPCFs).  Peak Democracy's OPCFs have the order and decorum of a public hearing so they are civil, fair and legal. They also are insightful, easy to use, and costs effective. 
The 20-40 age group is heavily comprised of people that are focused on their careers and/or families, and therefore they don't have the time or inclination to go to long, night-time public meetings. That's why Peak Democracy's service is so popular with that demographic.
We are working with dozens of cities, counties and elected officials across the US. They have used Peak Democracy's Open Town Hall service to launch over 500 forums.
To learn more, go to http://www.PeakDemocracy.com

author: Barry Crook
text: We have a specific city council goal this year to increase the involvement of Aspenites aged 20-40 in the civic process. I'm wondering how other jurisdictions have approached this age group and efforts to increase their participation in all aspects of civic life?
title: Civic Engagement in 20-40 year olds
